    Efficient calculation of a post hoc confidence bound

    Pierre Neuvial and Guillem Rigaill

    1 mars 2017

    Let us assume that we are given a JR controlling family in the sense of [1], that is, a family \(\mathfrak{R}=(R_k)_{1 \leq k \leq K}\) of sets such that

    \[ \mathbb{P}\left(\forall k = 1,\dots,K,\; |R_k(X)\cap \mathcal{H}_0| \leq \zeta_k(X)\right) \geq 1-\alpha\] It is argued in [1] that for any candidate subset of hypotheses \(R \subset \{1, \dots m\}\), the quantity

    \[ \overline{S}(R) = \max_{k \in \{1, \dots, K\}} \left( |R\cap R_k| -\zeta_k \right) \vee 0\] is a lower bound on the number of true positives in \(R\), i.e.:

    \[\mathbb{P}\bigg(\forall R \subset \{1,\dots,m\}, \, |R \cap \mathcal{H}_1(P)| \geq {S}(R) \bigg)\geq 1-\alpha\] In this note we propose a way to calculate \(\overline{S}(R)\) “efficiently” in the case where the \(R_k\) are nested, i.e. \(R_k \subset R_{k+1}\) for all \(k=1 \dots K-1\).

    Lemma 1.

    If \(\mathfrak{R}\) is a nested family, then for all \(k=1 \dots K-1\),

    \[\bigg(\left|R_{k+1} \setminus R_k \right| \leq \zeta_{k+1}-\zeta_k \bigg) \Rightarrow \bigg( \forall R \subset \{1 \dots m\}, |R \cap R_{k+1}| - \zeta_{k+1} \leq |R \cap R_{k}| - \zeta_{k} \bigg)\]

    Proof. Let \(R \subset \{1 \dots m\}\). By the nestedness of the family, we have

    \[ | R \cap R_{k+1}| - |R \cap R_k| = |R \cap (R_{k+1}\setminus R_{k})| \] \[ \leq | R_{k+1}\setminus R_{k}|\] \[ \leq \zeta_{k+1}-\zeta_k\] by assumption of the Lemma.

    A corollary of this result is that, in order to estimate the bound \(\overline{S}(R)\) for a given \(R\), the calculation of \(|R \cap R_k|\) for all \(k\) is not necessary. More precisely, it is possible to define a subfamily \((R_k)_{k \in \mathcal{S}}\) of \(\mathfrak{R}\) such that \(\forall R \in \{1\dots m\}\),

    \[ \overline{S}(R) = \max_{s \in \mathcal{S} } \left( |R\cap R_s| -\zeta_s \right) \vee 0\] Importantly, \(\mathcal{S}\) does not depend on \(R\). Obviously, this construction will be useful if the number of items in \(\mathcal{S}\) is substantially lower than \(|K|\). We will argue below that it is typically the case for the “linear family” defined in [1].

    The support of a reference family

    We define the support of the \(\mathfrak{R}\) family as the subset \(\mathcal{S}={s_1, \dots s_L}\) of \(\{1, \dots K\}\) such that

    \[ \forall l \in \{1 \dots L\}, \forall k \in \{s_l+1, \dots s_{l+1}-1\}, |R_k| - |R_{s_l}| \leq k-s_l \textrm{ and } |R_{s_{l+1}}| - |R_{s_l}| \leq s_{l+1} - s_l\]

    • justify that \(\mathcal{S}\) exists by state the algorithm to construct it

    References

    [1] Gilles Blanchard, Pierre Neuvial, Etienne Roquain, Post-hoc inference via joint family-wise error rate control, techreport.
